procedures.title: PROCEDURES
procedures.content:
Buoyancy: Procedures

Procedures

Getting Started

When you enter the lab, the meter stick will already be on the table and attached to the balancing device. You can drag and drop this device to a convenient space on your workbench.

Notice that the meter stick’s units are in centimeters. The meter stick's pivot point in this lab is the position on the stick at which it is held — in this case, 100 cm. The pivot point for this balancing device is between the two yellow arrows. To reposition the stick, simply drag it to the desired pivot point.

To add mass to the meter stick, double-click on it and select the appropriate weight from the list. To remove the weights, drag them all the way to the right, and off of the stick.

In this lab, you will link the beaker to the balancing device by dropping it onto any part of the metal stand. You will see the beaker snap into place.

For all of the experiments, be sure to record your units. You may need to convert them.

Experiment 1

Part 1: Measuring the Masses of Blocks

  1. Note that the meter stick is already pegged to its pivot point. Record this number in your notes. Be sure to save your notes.

  2. Place the metal block from the Instruments Shelf onto the meter stick near the 150 cm mark. Record this position.

  3. Add a 400 g mass to the stick and drag it to the 50 cm mark. Record this mass (m1) and its position.

  4. Add a 100 g mass to the stick. Drag the mass to a position that will balance the meter stick. Record this mass (m2)and its position.

  5. Remove the masses from the meter stick. Remove the block and place it in the recycling bin beneath the workbench.

  6. Repeat steps 2 - 5 for these blocks:
    • wood block
    • balsa block
    Skip step 3; this weight is not needed.

    7. Be sure to save your notes.

Part 2: Measuring the Buoyant Force and the Density of Fluids

  1. Place a 1,000 mL beaker from the Containers shelf onto the workbench.

  2. Add 700 mL of water from the Materials shelf to the beaker. Record this volume. Be sure to save your notes.

  3. Link the beaker to the balancing device by dropping it onto the metal stand.

  4. Place the metal block from the Instruments shelf onto the meter stick near the 150 cm mark. Record this position.
    You will see the device link to the block in the beaker.

  5. Add a 300 g mass to the stick. Drag the mass to a position that will balance the meter stick. Record this mass (m1) and its position.

  6. Record the new volume of the water in your notes.

  7. Discard the mass, block, and beaker.

Experiment 2: Measuring the Density of Blocks
  1. Place two beakers onto the workbench.

  2. Add 600 mL of water to each beaker.

  3. Place a wood block in one of the beakers.

  4. Place a balsa block in the other beaker.

  5. Measure and record the new volume in each beaker.

background.title: BACKGROUND
background.content:
Buoyancy: Background

Background

The concept of buoyancy is very familiar to most people. Anyone who has held a helium balloon knows that if you release the balloon, it will rise up into the air; or that if you put a rock into water, it will sink. It’s also true that if you put lead on liquid mercury, it will float. Whether something sinks or floats in a fluid depends on the buoyancy of the object in the surrounding medium.

In this lab, you will investigate buoyancy by placing objects into fluids. You will measure how much fluid is displaced and observe whether the object floats or sinks.

Density, Displacement, and Archimedes

Archimedes, the great mathematician and scientist, was once challenged to prove whether or not the King’s crown was made out of solid gold. In an ingenious experiment, he proposed a test to measure the density of the crown and then to determine whether the density of the crown matched the expected density of gold (19.3 g/mL).

The density, ρ, is defined as the mass, m, per volume, V, of an object. In mathematical terms:

Equation 1:          

For a simple object, such as a block or a sphere, calculating the volume of the object is trivial. However, it’s very difficult to calculate the volume of an irregularly shaped object, such as a crown.

In what came to be known as Archimedes’ Principle, Archimedes noticed that if you submerge an object in water, the volume of the object equals the volume of the displaced water. This is true regardless of the material that the object is made of. A hollow ball of filled with air and a solid ball made of lead with the same volumes will displace the same amount of water when submerged.

Archimedes placed the crown in a tub of water and measured how much the water rose up; he used this displacement to calculate the volume of the crown. He could then measure the mass of the crown and apply Equation 1 to find the volume. Using this procedure, he was able to show that the crown was not made of solid gold.

Buoyant Force

To understand whether an object will sink or float, we must first understand buoyancy. As you go deeper down into a fluid, the pressure you feel increases. This is due to gravity; the deeper you go, the more the mass of the fluid above presses down on you.

Near the surface of the ocean, the pressure is low because there isn’t much water pushing down on you. On the other hand, consider the Mariana Trench. At 10 km below the surface, it is the deepest part of the Earth's oceans. The pressure of water on a mass at the bottom of the Trench is over 1,000 times the atmospheric pressure. Submarines that travel to these deep ocean depths are specially designed to withstand incredible pressures.

Not only does pressure increase as an object is submerged deeper into a fluid, but if the object is held still, then the pressure acts equally in all directions at any given depth (i.e. the force pushing down equals the force pushing left, etc.). If the pressure does not act equally, there would be net movement in the fluid.

Now consider the diagram below, depicting a block submerged in water (which is one type of fluid). The arrows and their sizes indicate the relative pressure.

In this example, the block causes a net displacement of water equal to its volume (regardless of the material). Notice that the forces acting on the block from the left and right cancel each other out.

On the other hand, the pressure pushing up on the object is greater than the pressure pushing down on the object. This difference in pressure results in a net upward force, called the buoyant force. The buoyant force is independent of the density of the object on which it acts.

As you submerge an object, you must displace a volume of fluid equal to the volume of the submerged object. Functionally, this causes the fluid to rise up against gravity. The force required to lift this mass of fluid, mf, is equal to the buoyant force and is given by the expression:

Equation 2:          

It is convenient to consider the density of the fluid, ρf, and substitute Equation 1 into Equation 2 to get an expression for the buoyant force:


Equation 3:          
where V is the volume of displaced fluid.

The density of water is 1 g/mL. This equation holds true for fluids other than water.

The Physics of Floating and Sinking

Now we finally have the tools to understand why some objects float and why some sink.

We will define a downward acting force with a negative (-) sign. When an object of mass mo is submerged in a fluid, the force of gravity (Fg) pulls the object downward while the buoyant force pushes the object upward. The net force acting on the object is given by:

Equation 4:          

Measuring the Mass of Blocks

In Experiment 1, you will be using the apparatus to measure the buoyant force directly (if you have done our Torque lab, this apparatus will look familiar.) The apparatus consists of a meter stick suspended from a string at a pivot point. By adding mass to one side of the stick, you will be applying a force, F, at a distance L from the pivot point, creating a torque, τ, given by the following expression:

Equation 5:          

This torque will cause the meter stick to rotate. To return the meter stick to its equilibrium position (i.e. its position before the mass was added) you must apply an equal and opposite torque to the other side of the meter stick. You can do this by adding either one mass or multiple masses, as long as the torque on one side of the meter stick equals the torque on the other side of the meter stick.

If you have several masses, m1, …, mn that are placed at different distances from the pivot point, L1, …,Ln, then the net torque, τnet will be given by:

Equation 6:          

This is how the scale in a doctor’s office works. When you step on the scale, the balance tips. You then move a large mass — the coarse adjustment — to balance the scale (i.e. you move the mass to a defined distance from the pivot point). After you've used your large mass as a coarse adjustment, you use a smaller mass to do the fine adjustment (i.e. moving the masses to different lengths from the pivot point). You move the masses until the torque due to the masses equals the torque due to your weight.

In this lab, you will first measure the mass of a block by placing the block on one side of the meter stick, and will then add masses to the other side of the meter stick to get an equal but opposite torque (i.e. balance the meter stick). If the block with mass mBlock is hung a distance LBlock from the pivot point, then the torque due to the block, τBlock is equal to:

Equation 7:          

If you balance the system when you add two masses to the other side of the meter stick — m1 and m2 at distances L1 and L2  away from the pivot point, the total torque is equal to:

Equation 8:          

Now that the system is at equilibrium, we can equate Equations 7 and 8 to solve for the mass of the blockt:

Equation 9:          


Measuring the Buoyant Force of the Density of Fluids

You can now find the buoyant force by placing the block in a fluid. Recall that liquids and gasses are both fluids; a fluid is something that flows. However, while both take on the shape of their containers, liquids, unlike gasses, do not expand to fill their containers.

In both fluid situations in our lab — when the block is submerged in liquid water and when it is suspended in gaseous air — you measure F net. You will find that when the block is submerged in a liquid, its mass will be less than when it is in air. This difference is due to the buoyant force.

When the block is in air, the buoyant force is negligible and Fnet is (space inserted) approximately equal to Fg. When the block is submerged, the net force is given by Equation 4:

To measure the net force acting on the block when it is submerged (Fnet in Equation 4), you repeat the same procedure to balance the torques, measuring Fnet instead of the force due to gravity.

Thus, if you measure Fg when an object isn't submerged, and then Fnet when submerged, you can get a measurement of the buoyant force. If you know the volume of fluid displaced, you can also use Equation 4 to get the density of the fluid:

Equation 10:          

If we want to determine whether an object will sink or float, we can use Equation 1 to express the mass of the object as a having density, ρo and a volume v (equal to the volume of the fluid displaced!). Thus, Equation 4 becomes:

Equation 11:          

Remembering that a force is directed upward is given a positive sign, we can use Equation 11 to determine whether an object will:

  • float: go up because Fnet is positive
  • sink: go down because Fnet is negative
    • or
  • stay: remain in one place because Fnet is zero

This depends on the difference between the densities of the fluid and the object. If the fluid is denser than the object, the object will float. If the object is denser than the fluid, it will sink. We can now understand why the helium balloon floats: the density of helium is less than the density of air.

Another fascinating implication of this equation is that an object submerged in fluid will weigh less than it does out of the fluid because the buoyant force will always act opposing gravity.

(Note: If the object sinks to the bottom of the container, it is not being held at equilibrium due to the buoyant force. In this case, electrostatic interactions prevent the block from going all the way through the container. To describe the net force in this case, we will need a different equation than Equation 11. Equation 11 is true if the only forces acting on the object are 1) gravity and 2) the buoyant force.)

A submarine capitalizes on these principles to float or remain submerged. It has ballast tanks, which can be filled with either water or air. To dive, the submarine fills the ballast tanks with water, causing its density to become similar to the density of the water. Its mass increases while its volume remains the same. To surface, the submarine forces air into the ballast tanks, causing the density of the submarine to decrease and the submarine to rise up. This video shows a model of how ballast tanks work.

Why does a boat remain partially submerged rather than completely afloat on the surface of the water? This occurs because air can act as a fluid with a set density. The boat will rise up until the density of the boat equals the average density of the fluids surrounding it.

Equation 11 still holds in the case of air acting as a fluid and an object rising or sinking in water until Fnet is equal to zero. If an object is at equilibrium and not completely submerged, then Fnet = 0. (Recall, this will only work if the object does not sink to the bottom.) In this case, the volume of fluid displaced by the object, Vf, will not equal the total volume of the object, vo, since the entire object is not submerged.

Thus, Equation 11 becomes:


1234
5678

+++  + ha! 


Equation 12:          

We can rearrange this equation to see that:

Equation 13:          

Therefore, by measuring the water displaced, one can measure the density of the object. You will use this equation in Experiment 2 to find the density of blocks made of different materials.
